The Incarceration Crisis and Race
 By E.F. Winlsow 4-26-2005
 
 The Bureau of Justice Statistics released their annual numbers Tuesday, showing the proportion of inmates of the U.S. population in Federal and State prisons at an all time high. When including all the individuals involved in the parole or probation system, they reveal that nearly one in every 32 adults was under some type of correctional supervision. 
 
 The highest rate of increase of incarceration was in the Federal prison system (up 6.6%), followed by the local jails (up 3.9%), and the lowest increase was in the State prisons (up 1.4%). The average growth in the incarceration rate since 1995 was about 3.4%.
